• The drought is currently devastating most of Somalia, and neighboring regions. In Somalia, the worst affected regions are Bay, Bakool. • The agro pastoral livelihoods in the mainly crop dependent Bay and Bakool region are classified in Emergency (IPC 4) with most adjacent livelihoods classified in Crisis (IPC 3). The both the rural and urban and agro-pastoral livelihoods face large-scale food insecurity. • Figures by UNHCR in February 2017 place the new arrivals in Baidoa at 31,000 as consequence of drought and loss of livelihood as the reasons. The number is likely to increase as the IDPs continue stream in day after day. • Access to employment earnings are less than USD $50 per month while the Minimum Expenditure Basket (MEB) for Bay region is currently USD $93 up from $78 at the beginning of 2016. • The high rate of livestock losses (between 55 and 90% since the drought’s onset) is a major concern of malnutrition, as affected populations depend on livestock for milk, meat and income. • U.N. Humanitarian Coordinator for Somalia (in January 2017), warned that over 6 million Somalis, nearly half the population, are severely food insecure because of drought and continued fighting.
